section.para: The &program_name; message-sharing system is designed for people who have something to say, but who also value their anonymity. Importantly, anonymity is not the same thing as encryption, which protects the content of communication over the Internet. Anonymity, on the other hand, protects the people. &program_name; text and audio chat prevents the disclosure of its users' real-world identities by direct or indirect means.

This guide explains how to use the &chat_client; text and audio chat client. The client uses an &program_name; network to share one-on-one and group messages while protecting both the content of your conversations and identifying information about you. For technical information about how Echomix works, see blah. To learn why Echomix works as it does, see Frequent asked questions .

section.title: Requirements for the &chat_client; chat client
section.para: To use the &chat_client; chat client, you need a computer running the GNU/Linux operating system on x86-64 hardware. The &chat_client; software is provided as an AppImage package, and should run without problems on any modern Linux distribution, including, but not limited to, Ubuntu, Debian, openSUSE, CentOS, Fedora, and Arch.

An AppImage package contains all of the supporting software libraries needed to run the included application, so there is no need to install the software directly on your system. However, you do need to install AppImage itself on your system before you can run AppImage packages. For more information,. consult the procedures for installing application on your Linux distribution.

The &chat_client; client is available as an AppImage package from the &program_name; site at https://katzenpost.network/downloads. Complete the following procedure.
Download the the AppImage package to a convenient location on your computer.
In a terminal, navigate to the directory containing the &chat_client;-x86_64.AppImage file. Set the executable flag as follows: ~$ chmod +x &chat_client;-x86_64.AppImage
Note that you may need root permissions to perform this step.
You can now start Echo from a graphical file manager or directly at the command line: ~$ ./&chat_client;-x86_64.AppImage

section.title: Frequently asked questions
section.para: Users of conventional encrypted chat tools (Meta WhatsApp, Meta Messenger, Apple iMessage, Signal, etc.) may wonder, "Why should I care about that?" Many people may not care. However, businesses, governments, and criminals care very much about your identity and all of the information linked to it.

listitem.para: Internet businesses routinely harvest and sell sensitive identity data to profit from invasively personalized ads and other sources.

Governments, especially law enforcement and spy agencies, collect and store any data about identity, movements, employment, and political views that they can get their hands on, sacrificing the privacy of millions of innocent people to catch a tiny number of suspected criminals.
Actual criminals make daily use of the data they steal from these same businesses and governments, enabling identity theft, credit-card fraud, and blackmail.

section.para: Consequently, &program_name; users are likely to be drawn from the following demographics.

listitem.para: People and groups who are likely to be under surveillance by government entities, including corrupt police forces and intelligence agencies.
People facing business or government censorship.
Businesses aware of the dangers of leaking internal information to their local and global competitors or to their own or other governments.
Non-profit organizations engaging in advocacy that earns them enemies in high places with powerful surveillance capabilities.
People worried about the utter insecurity of personal data stored in both cloud and on-premises databases that are accessible from the Internet.
People who want to use the Internet for communication, but who viscerally detest being the raw material that feeds surveillance capitalism.
